title: 112_s3077
content: The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings related to the legislation. The Pro Football Hall of Fame's mission is to honor individuals who have made outstanding contributions to professional football, preserve historic documents and artifacts, educate the public about the sport's origin and promote its positive values. The Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963 with a charter class of 17 players. The Pro Football Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963, with a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors. There are 273 members elected to the Hall of Fame, each represented by a bronze bust, a Hall of Fame gold jacket, and a Hall of Fame ring. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, opened in 1963, has welcomed nearly 9 million visitors worldwide. The museum has expanded multiple times and houses the world's largest collection on professional football. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, opened in 1963, has welcomed nearly 9 million visitors worldwide. The museum's vast collection includes over 20,000 three-dimensional artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. It reaches a global audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various channels. The Fame Enshrinement Festival includes three nationally televised events, special events across the country, and educational outreach programs through the museum's video conferencing. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90% gold. Additionally, $1 silver coins will be minted weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver. The half-dollar clad coins minted under this Act weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The coins minted under this Act are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code, and considered numismatic items under section 5134 of the same code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. Design Requirements for the coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of professional football, with inscriptions of value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility within a one-year period starting January 1, 2016. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act before issuance, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received are promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits. The Pro Football Hall of Fame receives surcharges from coin sales for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits and there is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs issued annually. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin program limitation.
